raw_mentions: The displacement data were fit to a four-parameter equation and the dissociation constant (Kd) for relaxin was calculated to be 1.3 ± 0.22 nM in A; 1.37 ± 0.13 nM in B; and 0.86 ± 0.35 nM in C.

Here are the extracted sentences that meet the criteria:

1. The dissociation constant (K<sub>d</sub>) for relaxin was calculated as the mean ± S.E. of two separate regions on the same tissue: 1.3 ± 0.22 nM in the uterus (Fig. 2A), and 1.37 ± 0.13 nM in the normal heart (Fig. 2B), and 0.86 ± 0.35 nM in the estrogen-treated ovariectomized rat heart (Fig. 2C).
2. The dissociation constant (K<sub>d</sub>) for H1 relaxin was found to be 1.53 ± 0.04 nM.
3. The affinity of relaxin binding to the atria in estrogen-treated ovariectomized rats (K<sub>d</sub>=0.86 ± 0.35 nM, Fig. 2C) is not significantly different from that in intact female atria (1.37 ± 0.13 nM, Figure 2B).
4. The specificity of binding was demonstrated by the displacement of the binding of 100 pM <sup>32</sup>P-relaxin by 100 nM unlabeled relaxin (Fig. 1B) but not by 100 nM IGF-I (Genentech, Inc.) (Fig. 1C), insulin (Eli Lilly, Pearl River, N.Y.), angiotensin II, and atrial natriuretic peptide (Sigma, St. Louis, MO) (data not shown).
5. For relaxin binding displacement experiments, consecutive 16 µm sections were incubated with 100 pM of <sup>32</sup>P-relaxin in the absence and presence of increasing concentrations (serial three-fold increases) of unlabeled relaxin in the range of 0.1-100 nM.
